The one time I had to fly for a wedding my dad drove the chair across the country instead of flying it with me.

I asked if they had disabled assistance and they said yes they could help me with my carry on to the gate.

When I arrived they tried to charge me 200 for it and then when I refused the manager lifted my bad and said it's not heavy.  You can do it.

My neuroimmune disease says otherwise.﻿

text:
Structurally, the airline industry has some difficult hills to climb.  Capital expenditures are high (for the planes), most employees are unionized (no disapproval from me - go union!), and customers are trained to find the cheapest flights like it's a game.  On top of that, an airline can go bankrupt but still continue to operate - and this creates a competitive burden on the rest of the industry, because the recently bankrupted airline can renegotiate loans, maybe even employee concessions, etc.

It's hard to differentiate for higher fares.  Take Virgin America (please!) which had the most awesome in-flight safety video ever..ever.  They're being sold off to Alaskan airlines.﻿

author: TheOnni1

text:
Myers barely touches on the main point, which is that passengers/customers will do anything to get that cheap ticket.  As far as a single incident like United/Dao goes, Yes, that is the fault of the individuals, companies, and other entities involved.  There's no excuse for treating someone like that.

However, if customers are concerned about the airlines' treatment of passengers as a whole, look in the mirror.  Passengers get bumped from their flights tens of thousands of times every year, and it's approved by law.  Nobody complains that that is legal until they get hurt by it or there is a public incident like United/Dao, because deep down, people would rather save $10 on a flight.  These laws are there because people told their congressmen they wanted them there.

The airline industry is cutthroat and profit margins are razor-thin.  In addition, it's a business model that is easily upset.  One day of bad thunderstorms at a hub can wreck the whole quarter or even more.  As an illustration of this, IATA recently published a glowing report praising record profits for the airline industry and an unprecedented industry profit for the third year in a row.  However, if you read into the meat of the report, you'll read that by "record profits" IATA means that the airline industry made about what an average business makes, which is extremely rare.

If people don't want to get treated like cattle and bumped off their flights... sorry, folks, but goodbye affordable airfare.  You can't have it both ways.  Pick one.﻿

author: CaptainCore993

text:
123haninhk Mr Meyers is forgetting that the airline industry in the United States is still recovering from an abysmal decade in the early 2000s. Second, the airline industry is far from a free market race to the bottom. That just doesn't happen without GOVERNMENT occlusion. No more than 25% of American Airlines can be owned by foreign investors. That right there is why Virgin Atlantic was bought by Alaska despite Richard Branson not wanting it so. He wanted to compete. Localities make contracts with certain airlines to operate in their airports, which is why many airlines don't fly certain places. It's not a free market. Problems like this are never a free market. They are government constraints that limit the free market without the added benefit of subsidies that you find in other countries. Lufthansa, British airways, Air France are all subsidized directly. This is the United States indirectly subsidizing airlines by limiting competition. Races to the bottom don't happen in a true free market. So we can either try to further deregulate, or we can directly subsidize like the rest of the world. But Americans like to have a boogie man. That boogie man of late has been big business... And of course the only solution is to give its creator more authority.... It's genius. 

Please do not confuse this with safety protocols and faa regulations. This is much more macro economic theory. Have a set standard for safe flying in place and allow a market to compete freely within those boundaries. That's all that is needed. And that's not what we have.﻿

Airlines overbook because they know from statistics how many seats will be left empty for various reasons (like missed connections). Is one way to keep fares low in a competitive market and they do their best to keep the risk at minimum.

author: Randal Jeffrey

text: If involuntarily bumped they're required by law to pay you 2x the cost of the ticket for a flight arrival 2-4 hours later, and 4x the cost if delayed over 4 hours, up to a maximum of $1250. If you volunteer to take a different flight when offered compensation that's your choice. You can also take whatever compensation they offer if you think it is more valuable than the cash/check required by law (sometimes they offer vouchers and/or frequent flyer miles).﻿
author: J H

text:
Randal Jeffrey In what country, and what currency? In Europe they are required to reimburse you with a flat rate of €250 if the flight is shorter than 1500 km (€125 if the delay is less than 2 hours), €400 for longer flights within EU and if the flight is between 1500 km and 3500 km and €600 for flights longer than 3500 km and outside of EU. If you voluntarily accept denied boarding with another settlement, you can't claim the flat rate.

There's no cap, but usually they will find someone who takes the cash and wait for the next flight. But at times there have been quite high sums to get someone to wait for the next flight. And a smart crew takes care of this before boarding, not when they are already seated waiting for push back.﻿
